message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Debate "character" for 德">
The author is considering "character" for 德. Those who voted against it — what is your single strongest objection to "character"? Those who voted for it — what is its single strongest advantage?

Also: we now know 性 does NOT appear as a standalone technical term in the collection, so the "nature" collision concern is off the table.

Brief responses — one strongest point each.
</teammate-message>

input.summary: Character alone is too ambiguous in running text
input.content:
**Strongest objection to bare "character"**: Ambiguity in running text without a modifier.

"The character of a person" in English defaults to meaning personality or moral character. "A character in the story" means a fictional person. "Chinese characters" means 汉字. The reader must disambiguate every occurrence. With "inherent character" or "constitutive character," the modifier locks in the intended sense -- "the quality that makes a thing what it is" -- and the reader never has to guess.

If 性 is confirmed off the table, I would accept **"constitutive character"** as a strong alternative to "inherent character." The adjective does the essential disambiguating work either way. Bare "character" does not.

routing.summary: Character alone is too ambiguous in running text
routing.content:
**Strongest objection to bare "character"**: Ambiguity in running text without a modifier.

"The character of a person" in English defaults to meaning personality or moral character. "A character in the story" means a fictional person. "Chinese characters" means 汉字. The reader must disambiguate every occurrence. With "inherent character" or "constitutive character," the modifier locks in the intended sense -- "the quality that makes a thing what it is" -- and the reader never has to guess.

If 性 is confirmed off the table, I would accept **"constitutive character"** as a strong alternative to "inherent character." The adjective does the essential disambiguating work either way. Bare "character" does not.

content.text: Bare "character" is too ambiguous -- it defaults to personality, moral character, or fictional character in English. A modifier is essential to lock in the intended sense. With the 性 collision off the table, I'm open to either "inherent character" or "constitutive character" -- the adjective is what does the disambiguating work.
